concern:
Ok, I am very confused and frustrated, and I don't know what to do here.

So, I am in a very interdisciplinary major (won't say what because it's a VERY small department and it will immediately doxx myself and this person) and we have an approved course list that comes out every semester that tells us what those courses "count" for in the major. There are some staples that never change and what requirements they fulfill, but the real reason this list is sent out is so we know how more niche classes (say, ones that are only offered in Fall or Spring, or only offered in even years, etc.) can be used to meet our major requirements. 

For years, the list archives show CLASS 101 as fulfilling X, Y, and Z requirements. Now, I know the curriculum hasn't changed because I know the person teaching the class. Yes, it is the same professor. It is one of the "staples" I mentioned above. It's offered every semester, and the core requirements do not change. Now it's listed as only fulfilling X requirement for the major. The class, again, has not changed in any way. I have even confirmed with the prof that, outside of writing new test questions to make sure nobody cheats, the content covered will remain identical and they have no idea why it might suddenly be different. 

This is also now true for CLASS 102, CLASS 103, CLASS 104, etc. In previous semesters, they have been consistently used to fulfill A, B, and C. Now they only fulfill A. 

What this means, essentially, is that I am going to have to stay another YEAR (I was supposed to graduate in Fall) to complete more classes to fulfill requirements that the classes I ALREADY TOOK should have covered, because now, suddenly, they don't fulfill those requirements anymore. Literally just because this one person said so. Or, worst case scenario, I will max out my units (I'm a senior and was a transfer so I'm already close to doing that) and not be allowed to finish at all since my uni won't let anyone enroll in Fall or Spring if they have over 132 units. All because my adviser has changed the requirements. 

I've tried to email the adviser about this change, and they said it should have always been listed this way and I'll just have to take these other classes to make up for the changes. Except, like, we went over a course plan together. TWICE. And these classes fulfilled those requirements *then*. It feels like this person just randomly pulled these new rules out of thin air at the last minute, and it's gonna tank me. 

I am one of only maybe 10 students in my sub-specialty, so this isn't something that screws over the *whole* department. But, like... I am still fully at risk of not getting a degree now because my adviser has shifted the goalposts at the last minute. It's been established for YEARS that these classes fulfill these distribution requirements for the major, and now suddenly I'm expected to just accept that a bunch of my credits won't count toward my degree anymore??? Also, what is stopping this major adviser from pulling this nonsense again if I do stay an extra year and they decide I can't be on the degree list because they've changed the requirements yet again??? 

Who can I talk to about this? I am (obviously) livid and I have the receipts. Unless my adviser can produce a darn good reason to suddenly change the major requirements with NO WARNING, or why these classes can't count for students who have already taken them, I feel like this is worth going higher up. I just don't know who "higher up" is. The department chair? The dean of the college? 

Thanks.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! How are you doing today? Is there something specific you'd like to talk about, or should we just see where the conversation takes us?
I'm feeling pretty stressed and frustrated right now, thanks for asking. I'd like to talk about some challenges I'm facing with my academic plans, if that's okay.
Of course, that sounds like a lot to deal with. It's great that you're reaching out to talk about these challenges. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your academic plans?

I'm really frustrated because some unexpected changes in my major requirements have thrown off my graduation plans. It's making me anxious about potentially having to extend my time in school or even not finishing at all.

It's completely understandable that these unexpected changes are causing you stress and anxiety. It's tough when you feel like your plans are up in the air. But remember, you're not alone in thislots of students face challenges like this. Have you reached out to your academic advisor or department for guidance on how to navigate these changes?

Yes, I've already reached out to my academic advisor about these changes, but it hasn't resolved my concerns. It's left me feeling even more anxious about how this might derail my graduation timeline.

It's tough when the initial steps you take don't immediately resolve your concerns. But remember, this is just the beginning of the process. You've already taken a proactive step by reaching out to your advisor. Let's brainstorm some other steps you could take to gain more clarity and ease your anxiety. Would you like to start with some potential options?

Yes, I'd like to brainstorm some potential options to help me feel more in control. I'm still feeling anxious about how these unexpected changes could affect my future plans, so any advice would be appreciated.
Okay, let's start by breaking down the problem. Can you list out the specific changes that are causing you the most anxiety? Maybe we can tackle them one by one and come up with a plan for each.

The specific changes causing me the most anxiety are that certain classes I've already taken are no longer counting toward key requirements in my major, forcing me to take additional courses. This is making me feel even more uncertain about my graduation timeline and overall academic progress.

That's a tough situation, but let's focus on what we can control. One option is to explore if there are any alternative courses you can take that will fulfill those requirements. Have you looked into that possibility yet?

I've considered looking into alternative courses to fulfill the requirements, but I haven't pursued it yet because the sudden changes have left me feeling overwhelmed and unsure where to begin. This uncertainty is really amplifying my anxiety about my graduation plans.

It's natural to feel overwhelmed and uncertain when unexpected changes arise. But remember, you've come this far already, and you can handle this challenge too. Let's start by taking one step at a time. Maybe you could schedule another meeting with your academic advisor to discuss potential alternative courses and create a new graduation plan together. Do you think that would be a good first step?

Yes, scheduling another meeting with my academic advisor could be a good first step to seek clarity, though I'm still feeling anxious that it might not resolve the ongoing uncertainty about my graduation plans. I'm willing to try it to regain some sense of control over the situation.

That's great, it's a step in the right direction. It's normal to feel anxious about the uncertainty, but taking action can help alleviate some of that anxiety. And remember, even if the meeting doesn't resolve everything, it's still progress and you can continue to work towards finding solutions. Let's stay positive and keep moving forward.

Thank you for the encouragement it's helpful to hear that taking action can make a difference. I'm still feeling anxious about these unexpected changes, but I'll try to focus on staying positive and moving forward with that next meeting.

dialogue_conv:
